title: If the Average Person Did This for 6 Months, They'd Be Unrecognizable to Their Friends & Family
author: Tim Denning

sections.heading: Main
sections.content:
# If the Average Person Did This for 6 Months, They'd Be Unrecognizable to Their Friends & Family

### The blueprint that'll obliterate your roadblocks in life (I guarantee it)

Share

Being average is hell on Earth.

It‚Äôs a boring, lifeless, pandering, people-pleasing disaster that leads you to a dead end, and shortly after, off a cliff. Don‚Äôt do it, it‚Äôs a bear trap.

You can do better than average without much extra effort.

> ‚ÄúThere is no normal/average. A ‚Äònormal person‚Äô is what is left after society has squeezed out all unconventional opinions and aspirations out of a human being.‚Äù‚Äì Sylvia Path

‚ÄúThere is no normal/average. A ‚Äònormal person‚Äô is what is left after society has squeezed out all unconventional opinions and aspirations out of a human being.‚Äù

‚Äì Sylvia Path

Why would you let society beat you down and leave you with scraps and food stamps?

Amazon founder Jeff Bezos goes a step further and says ‚ÄúThe world pulls at you in an attempt to make you normal.‚Äù Your job is to fight the resistance, to stay the hell away from normal and the terrible rewards it offers.

I‚Äôm going to help you do it in the next 6 months. Here‚Äôs the blueprint below.

Being average is a sin ‚Äì Zach Pogrob

# Pretend rules don‚Äôt exist

The nanny police are gonna light my skinny ass on fire for this one.

I‚Äôve been lucky to meet many ultra-successful people in my life. Everyone from Tony Robbins to Gary Vee. When I worked in banking I got to meet the founders of some of the biggest companies in the world.

One thing always stuck with me: they believed there are basically zero rules.

None of these people ever let rules get in the way. They saw rules as guidelines at best. Often, if they wanted to disrupt an industry they had to disregard the rules and even create new ones.

Average people don‚Äôt do this. They see rules as fixed roadblocks that scream ‚ÄúComputer says no, buddy!‚Äù Well, you can make the computer say yes to your dreams if you‚Äôre willing to.

Rules are often set by gatekeepers who want to keep the power and control for themselves. My favorite part about living in these modern times is the internet keeps giving the middle finger to the rules.

Just a few months ago banks were still trying to block Bitcoin. As of a few hours ago we‚Äôve gone parabolic. The internet said ‚ÄúF*ck traditional money‚Äù and society has finally accepted it.

Whether you‚Äôre a crypto bro or not doesn‚Äôt matter. The point is the rules are being rewritten every day. Why can‚Äôt you do the same? Hint: you can.

# Have conversations with strangers

Your measure of success comes down to how many uncomfortable conversations you‚Äôre willing to have. And talking to strangers is as uncomfortable as it gets.

I‚Äôve been studying Timothy Leary lately. He‚Äôs most famous for his thoughts on LSD.

He‚Äôs a total tripper in many ways, but gee does he have some kickass, mind-bending views (must be all the magic mushrooms). He said this:

> The more you try to fit in, the more you feel like an outsider, watching the ‚Äònormal people‚Äô as they go about their automatic existences.

> The more you try to fit in, the more you feel like an outsider, watching the ‚Äònormal people‚Äô as they go about their automatic existences.

The more you try to fit in, the more you feel like an outsider, watching the ‚Äònormal people‚Äô as they go about their automatic existences.

This hit me hard. I‚Äôve never fit in. I‚Äôve always been a weirdo.

In society Timothy says we have club passwords like ‚ÄòHave a nice day‚Äô and ‚ÄòWeather‚Äôs awful today, eh?‚Äô But we‚Äôre dying to say forbidden things such as ‚ÄòTell me something that makes you cry‚Äô or ‚ÄòWhat do you think deja vu is for?‚Äô

I often think to myself when I meet a stranger, ‚ÄúYeah but why do what you do?!‚Äù

Timothy says if you want to escape the hell of average, you must take more chances on having conversations with strangers.

> Everybody carries a piece of the puzzle.Nobody comes into your life by mere coincidence.Trust your instincts.Do the unexpected.Find the others.

Everybody carries a piece of the puzzle.

Nobody comes into your life by mere coincidence.

Trust your instincts.

Do the unexpected.

Find the others.

Inside the minds of strangers is the wisdom you could never figure out on your own. Stop drowning in loneliness and frustration and reach out to a new person every day for the next 6 months.

Watch your network explode. Watch your life change forever.

Always stick to what makes you weird, odd, strange, different. That‚Äôs your source of power ‚Äì Robert Greene

# Do things that remind you that you‚Äôre not average

Our identity is a powerful drug.

It determines the decisions we make and even the career we choose. Transforming your identity is crucial. Once you escape the label of average you‚Äôve got to maintain it.

That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs crucial to do things that remind you that you‚Äôre not like everyone else.

It‚Äôs why I write online. It reminds me I‚Äôm a weirdo. It‚Äôs why I say crazy statements in front of local government such as ‚ÄúBut what if they‚Äôre pedos?‚Äù or ‚ÄúCould they be a charity pretending to do good while quietly doing evil?‚Äù

I get all sorts of crazy stares when I say the quiet parts out loud. The more you do it the more addictive it gets.

Every day it‚Äôs important to take weird actions or you‚Äôll get handcuffed by #normal and end up a boring person who follows the rules, never uses their creativity, and makes a decade feel like a year.

# The two big choices in life

#1 Take risks

#2 Work for those who take risks

Average people choose option two. They can‚Äôt stomach taking any risk at all. They focus on the downsides, the risks, and the failure they feel is a guarantee.

But if you don‚Äôt take risks all you end up with are regrets that rot your mind slowly over time. It‚Äôs mental torture if you let it happen.

I prefer to take calculated risks. I do my research. I expect failure to happen. And when it does, I figure out why so I can learn from it. I also learn from other people‚Äôs failures so I don‚Äôt have to make the same mistakes.

Right now, write down all of the risks you took in the last 12 months. If you end up with a blank page then you‚Äôre in the fast lane for mediocrity.

The good news is you can escape. Start taking calculated risks.

# Adopt this skill that takes seconds to learn

The average person moves at the pace of a snail.

There‚Äôs no urgency. They continuously shift goals to ‚Äòsomeday, mate.‚Äô They can‚Äôt stick to anything. Their habits list is full of heroin addictions like TikTok.

All you have to do to reverse these diabolical outcomes is adopt a sense of urgency.

* Set deadlines.
* Tell people your expectations.
* Be unreasonable in how quick you need other people to take action.
* Make your 10-year goals 6-month goals.

Set deadlines.

Tell people your expectations.

Be unreasonable in how quick you need other people to take action.

Make your 10-year goals 6-month goals.

Going faster doesn‚Äôt require extra brains or a 4-year college degree.

It just needs you to understand you could die any day now, so hurry the f*ck up and make your dreams a reality or you‚Äôll miss out on life (pardon my French).

# There are only two kinds of issues in life

1. Skill issues
2. Will issues

Skill issues

Will issues

Average people are overskilled. And people who think they don‚Äôt have the right skills are often just lacking will.

A lack of will is often covered up with perfectionism, complexity, overthinking, seeking out endless free mentors, or even believing you need more resources (money).

‚ÄúWill‚Äù is emotional intelligence. ‚ÄúSkill‚Äù is intellectual intelligence.

As we move out of the over information age, intelligence and skill acquisition are becoming less relevant. What you need is the will.

The will to be bold.The will to help others.The will to make a change.The will to reprogram your mind.The will to push yourself beyond your comfort zone.The will to live rather than be an NPC (non-player character).

# Do the boring things that are often missed

The last step is to do the boring things average people think are cliche and overly simplistic. To become unrecognizable in 6 months, do this:

* Eat food that gives you energy (instead of makes you feel like sh*t)
* Keep track of everything you‚Äôre grateful for (daily)
* Replace Netflix with auto-biographical books
* Walk in nature every day
* Help those with nothing
* Write online every day
* Spend time with family
* Quit all forms of p*rn
* Sleep for 8 hours

Eat food that gives you energy (instead of makes you feel like sh*t)

Keep track of everything you‚Äôre grateful for (daily)

Replace Netflix with auto-biographical books

Walk in nature every day

Help those with nothing

Write online every day

Spend time with family

Quit all forms of p*rn

Sleep for 8 hours

This list makes me sound like a self-help listicle guru. Good. Doing the opposite of 99% of people and being uncool is the fastest path to your version of success.

# Final Thought

If the average person did these things above, they‚Äôd be unrecognizable to their friends & family in 6 months.

Family and friends will start to say ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve changed.‚Äù Good. People will either accept the new you or keep trying to hold you back.

Choose wisely.

How else can people escape being average? Tell me in the comments section below, so we can all learn from you.

---

I send this email weekly. If you would also like to receive it, join the 164,000+ other smart people who absolutely love it today.

üëâ If you enjoy reading this post, feel free to share it with friends! Or feel free to click the ‚ù§Ô∏è button on this post so more people can discover it on Substack üôè

Share
